questions.prompt: What was Jesus correcting when Nicodemus assumed the kingdom could be entered through heritage and religious status?
choices: The belief that birth into Israel guarantees kingdom life
That stricter morality is the key requirement to qualify
That temple attendance and reputation automatically secure entrance
That the kingdom is mainly entered by gaining more religious knowledge

questions.prompt: In John 3, why does Jesus use “birth” language instead of “try harder” language?
choices: Because religious training naturally produces a new heart over time
Because spiritual life is received by God’s action, not self-produced
Because effort and discipline are the main way a person becomes acceptable to God
Because a person’s family background eventually shapes them into the kingdom

questions.prompt: “Born of water and of the Spirit” most directly points to what theme in the lesson?
choices: The outward sign of baptism that normally follows salvation
A ritual washing that automatically produces salvation
Cleansing and inward renewal promised by God, accomplished by the Spirit
The washing power of Scripture alone apart from the Spirit’s work

questions.prompt: According to the lesson, what can the “flesh” produce at best?
choices: A spiritual nature that pleases God without change
A heart that loves God by nature
A clean conscience that replaces the need for new birth
More flesh — behavior polishing without inward rebirth

questions.prompt: Which statement best matches the “new creature” emphasis tied to 2 Corinthians 5:17?
choices: A believer receives a new center of gravity: new desire and direction under a new Master
A believer is mainly given a second chance to prove themselves
A believer becomes immediately perfect in thoughts and actions
A believer’s past doesn’t matter anymore, so repentance is unnecessary

questions.prompt: Acts 3:19 presents repentance and conversion leading to what two outcomes?
choices: A new set of religious duties to keep for acceptance
Sins blotted out and times of refreshing from the Lord’s presence
Immediate public trust and restored reputation
A guaranteed easier life and fewer struggles

questions.prompt: In the lesson, repentance is best described as:
choices: A private regret that matters only if you feel it strongly
A shame-based punishment that keeps you fearful
An ongoing posture—turning from sin and toward God as the Spirit works
A one-time doorway you outgrow once you mature

questions.prompt: Psalm 51 shows repentance as primarily concerned with:
choices: Avoiding consequences and managing appearances
Balancing the scales by earning forgiveness through effort
Proving to others you changed so they accept you again
Restored fellowship with God and inner cleansing

questions.prompt: Which pairing reflects the lesson’s warning about the enemy twisting repentance?
choices: Fear: “If I confess, God will reject me” / Pride: “I don’t need to confess; I’m fine”
Fear: “Only confess small sins” / Pride: “Only confess when caught”
Fear: “Never admit sin at all” / Pride: “God doesn’t care about sin anyway”
Fear: “Confess only when you feel strong” / Pride: “Confess so people admire you”

questions.prompt: What does Psalm 51 call “the sacrifices of God”?
choices: Giving money to make up for past sin
A broken spirit and a broken, contrite heart God will not despise
Public fasting that shows everyone you’re serious
Religious routine done consistently to earn mercy

questions.prompt: In 1 John 5:11–13, assurance is grounded primarily in:
choices: Your ability to explain every doctrine without mistakes
A spotless track record after conversion
God’s testimony (“record”) about His Son and eternal life
How powerful your worship feelings are week to week

questions.prompt: According to the lesson, “This is the record” functions like:
choices: A slogan meant to motivate you when you’re down
A private opinion you choose to adopt
A church tradition that varies by denomination
A courtroom-like witness statement—God’s sworn testimony

questions.prompt: What is the sharp line 1 John draws to clarify who has life?
choices: Those who have the Son have life; those who do not have the Son do not have life
Those who attend church consistently have life
Those who avoid doubt completely have life
Those who behave well have life

questions.prompt: In John 10, the believer’s security is pictured as resting in:
choices: The believer’s ability to never stumble again
The Shepherd’s giving of life and keeping power—no one can pluck them out
The sheep’s consistency and personal willpower
The strength of the community holding them accountable

questions.prompt: Which statement best reflects the lesson’s view of true assurance?
choices: Assurance is earned by years of steady obedience
Assurance is mainly about feeling close to God every day
Assurance prepares you to tell your testimony with gratitude, not fear
Assurance means you never have questions or fears again

questions.prompt: In Ephesians 2, Paul starts the story of salvation with:
choices: What the church helped you accomplish through discipline
What your upbringing set you up to become
What you promised God you would do from now on
What God did—He “quickened” (made alive) the dead

questions.prompt: The lesson describes grace as:
choices: God coming all the way to the dead and bound, giving life where there was none
God meeting you halfway if you prove sincerity
God rewarding your improvement after you clean yourself up
God overlooking sin without ever dealing with justice

questions.prompt: “Not of works, lest any man should boast” is used to show:
choices: Only certain religious works count toward acceptance
God saves in a way that shuts down pride and self-congratulation
Works can earn salvation if you maintain them long enough
Works are meaningless and should be avoided

questions.prompt: According to the lesson, good works are:
choices: The root cause of salvation
A way to keep salvation once you’ve received it
The fruit of being God’s workmanship—created in Christ to walk in them
A substitute for repentance and faith

questions.prompt: The “bedrock” beneath new birth, repentance, and assurance is:
choices: Human determination and willpower
Religious ceremony that seals salvation
Spiritual experiences that confirm your worthiness
Grace—God’s initiative in salvation

questions.prompt: Hebrews 11 presents faith as “substance” and “evidence.” In the lesson, that means faith:
choices: Makes God’s promised realities weighty and present, even when unseen
Is mainly confidence that things will work out if you stay positive
Is the same thing as certainty you’ll never struggle again
Is blind guessing with no reason

questions.prompt: In the lesson’s framing, Hebrews 11 is primarily:
choices: A chapter mainly about celebrating human greatness
Battlefield encouragement to endure when obedience is costly
A detached inspirational chapter for posters
A list meant to entertain more than instruct

questions.prompt: “Without faith it is impossible to please him” is explained as:
choices: Faith being optional as long as you do good works
Faith being mostly an emotional feeling of closeness
Faith being the fitting posture toward the living God who has spoken
God only accepts people who never fail

questions.prompt: According to Hebrews 11:6, faith includes believing:
choices: God overlooks unbelief as long as you’re sincere
God exists and can be controlled if you say the right words
God only helps people who help themselves first
God is, and He rewards those who diligently seek Him

questions.prompt: Galatians 2:20 is used to show that faith is not only how you start with Christ, but how you:
choices: Live daily—“Christ liveth in me” shaping identity and obedience
Avoid hardship by staying confident
Replace repentance with self-assurance
Earn spiritual status through discipline

questions.prompt: In Matthew 5:6, Jesus blesses those who hunger and thirst after:
choices: Religious knowledge and spiritual experiences
Righteousness—what aligns with God’s will and character
Approval from others that proves you’re doing well
Comfort and success

questions.prompt: The lesson stresses hunger is not:
choices: A sign of life
Something God intends to satisfy over time
Something you must manufacture through hype
Something you can feel during dryness

questions.prompt: The promise “they shall be filled” is explained as:
choices: A guarantee of constant emotional highs
Proof that mature believers never struggle again
A reward mainly for disciplined personalities
God Himself filling the hunger He creates; satisfaction found where God says it is

questions.prompt: Psalm 42’s deer imagery (“panteth”) is used to picture:
choices: A soul gasping with real need for the living God
A calm, casual interest in God
A person who has outgrown worship and no longer needs it
A believer who never experiences discouragement

questions.prompt: A key move in Psalm 42 is the believer learning to:
choices: Prove faith by never feeling down
Talk to his soul and command hope in God instead of surrendering to despair
Withdraw from God’s people until the mood passes
Ignore emotions completely as unspiritual
